Fig. 1 One-pot synthesis of the bimetallic catalyst by redox deposition: (a) addition of silica in deionized water, (b) addition of nickel or copper precursor, (c) addition of NaBH4 under argon atmosphere, and (d) addition of platinum precursor. These steps are followed by filtration and drying at 110 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Schematic depiction of the redox deposition method: (a) Primary metals (Ni) reduced and deposited over the silica support, (b) Pt metal ions ([PtCl6]2-) approaching the primary metal sites, and (c) Pt ions being reduced and primary metals being oxidized to (Ni2+) ions. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Powder XRD patterns at an expanded scale over a narrower angle range of silica-supported monometallic and bimetallic catalysts prepared by the redox deposition method (a) as-prepared and (c) reduced Ni-containing samples; (b) as-prepared and (d) reduced Cu-containing samples. (2theta: 37.5-50°; step size: 0.02; scanning rate: 0.1 step/s). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Powder XRD patterns over a narrower angle range of (a) as-prepared and (b) reduced silica-supported NiPt samples prepared by the redox deposition method. The NiPt* series were prepared using the same method and under the same conditions as the NiPt samples, but with an additional step involving reduction of the oxidized Ni cations in the solution by NaBH4. (2theta: 37.5-50°, step size: 0.02, scanning rate: 0.1 step/s). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Powder XRD patterns at an expanded scale over a narrower angle for reduced catalysts prepared by the redox deposition method and incipient wetness (IW) impregnation method. The IW samples had Ni:Pt and Cu:Pt ratios similar to NiPt (4:1) and CuPt (4:1) catalyst measured by XRF results. (2theta: 35-50°, step size: 0.02, scanning rate: 0.1 step/s). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TPR profiles (m/z = 18) of the NiPt and NiPt* samples (0.1 g) under a H2 flow of 100 cm3 min-1. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TPR profiles (m/z = 18) of the CuPt samples (0.1 g) under a H2 flow of 100 cm3 min-1. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Pt 4f and (b) Ni 2pcore-level spectra of reduced and passivated silica-supported Ni, Pt and NiPt samples prepared by the redox deposition and incipient wetness (IW) method. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) Pt 4f and (b) Cu 2p core-level spectra of reduced and passivated silica-supported Cu, Pt and CuPt samples prepared by the redox deposition and incipient wetness (IW) method. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Turnover frequency based on the number of CO uptake sites for methane combustion reaction as a function of temperature with CH4 (20%), O2 (3%) for (a) NiPt catalysts (b) CuPt catalysts. Arrhenius plots of the turnover frequency for the methane combustion reaction as a function of temperature for (c) NiPt catalysts (d) CuPt catalysts. Graphical abstract A one-pot redox deposition method is described to prepare silica-supported bimetallic NiPt and CuPt catalysts using differences in standard reduction potentials. The synthesis involved the initial reduction of non-noble metal ions (Ni2+ and Cu2+) by NaBH4, followed by reduction of Pt ions by these reduced metals. Alloy formation and phase purity were established by X-ray diffraction (XRD), bulk composition by X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and surface composition by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Alloy formation was enhanced by increase in the amount of base metals available to reduce Pt, or through the use of excess NaBH4 after redox deposition. The catalysts were evaluated for methane oxidation at 300-400 °C and atmospheric pressure. Reference samples prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation (IW) method had inferior performance and characteristics. The redox deposition method provides a simple and versatile protocol for the preparation of bimetallic alloys between noble metals and base metals. Keywords Bimetallic catalyst nickel platinum copper platinum noble metal and base metal alloy reduction potential redox deposition method 1 Introduction Supported bimetallic alloys are important materials because of their many uses as catalysts for a variety of reactions at reducing [1–6] and oxidizing [7,8] conditions, and their applications as electrodes in electrochemical devices [9,10]. There has been extensive research on the use of bulk bimetallic alloy catalysts from the first half of the 20th century with early reports by Hedvall [11] and Rienacker and Bommel [12], and other studies associated with names like Schwab [13], Dowden [14], Eley [15], Bond [16], Emmett [17], and Hall [18]. Subsequent investigations of supported bimetallic alloy catalysts were reported by Sinfelt et al. [19] and the groups of Boudart [20], Swift and Bozik [21], and Anderson [22]. These studies, primarily in the area of catalytic reforming of petroleum fractions, stimulated interest in the use of bimetallic alloy catalysts for other reactions [3,23]. The applications of bimetallic alloys take advantage of the fact that they display catalytic properties that are distinct from those of their two metal components. Studies since the 1960s suggested that the unique catalytic properties of bimetallic alloys were associated with changes in their electronic and geometric structures [24,25]. The electronic contribution was denoted as a ligand effect [26], in analogy to the function of substituents on metallic complexes. The geometric contribution was called an ensemble effect [26], to account for the participation of multiple surface atoms, and is related to structure-sensitivity [27]. The preparation of bimetallic alloy catalysts is challenging because separate entities of the individual metal components can form. Various synthesis methods have been investigated to achieve intimate metal-metal interactions [23,28,29], such as impregnation [30,31], deposition-precipitation [29], electrostatic adsorption [32], colloidal deposition [33], ion-exchange [34,35], and electroless deposition [36]. The methods are all effective for the preparation of supported bimetallic samples. The electroless deposition (ED) method involves the selective deposition of a secondary metal salt onto the surface of an activated supported primary metal by electrochemical reduction. The synthesis of catalysts with bimetallic surfaces [37,38,39] by the use and control of an electroless bath, reducing agent, bath temperature, and pH reveal bimetallic core-shell structures with strong surface interactions between the two metals [39,40]. However, simultaneous nucleation of the depositing metal into monometallic particles can occur unless stable precursor complexes are used in the electroless bath. The galvanic displacement-reduction (GDR) method is a variation of the ED method where the surface of a noble metal with a low reduction potential, activated with a suitable liquid-phase reducing agent and in the presence of protecting polymers, reduces another noble metal with a high reduction potential. This method has been used for the synthesis of PdAu [41], PtAu [42] and PdPt [43] bimetallic compounds. Galvanic replacement has been applied extensively in the field of electrocatalysis to prepare bimetallic catalysts active for the oxygen reduction reaction [44,45]. A key motivation has been to reduce the amount of expensive Pt used in the alloys and to synthesize core-shell nanoparticles [45,46,47]. The present paper reports a redox deposition (RD) method that is a variation of the GDR method that allows the use of base metal components. The RD method differs from the GDR method in two ways. In the RD method, the precursor salt of the non-noble metal is initially deposited on the support, negating the use of protecting polymers, and the subsequent treatment to decompose the polymer. The RD method also uses NaBH4 instead of ethanol or ethylene glycol as the reducing agent. Other groups have previously utilized relative reduction potentials to prepare noble metal-base metal pairs [48,49,50,51,52,53]. Bai and coworkers synthesized hollow Pt nanospheres by using citrate-capped Co nanoparticles as sacrificial templates [48]. Maillard and coworkers prepared hollow PtNi nanoparticles through the combined action of galvanic displacement and the nanoscale Kirkendall effect, and notably observed the preferential reduction of Ni ions by NaBH4 in a mixed solution of Ni and Pt precursors [49]. Sarkar and Manthiram synthesized Pt@Cu core-shell nanoparticles by using excess amount of NaBH4 for the stepwise reduction of Cu and Pt ions [50]. Konya and coworkers synthesized porous CuPt and CuPd nanotubes by exposing preformed Cu nanowires to Pt and Pd precursors in a separate reaction vessel [51]. Yamashita and coworkers prepared CoPd nanoparticles by using synthesized Co seeds to reduce Pd ions in a different vessel [52]. Yang and coworkers synthesized Cu-containing bimetallic nanoparticles at elevated temperatures (>100 °C) and with excess amount of oleylamine [53]. These studies used sacrificial templates [49,49], excess reductants [49,50,53], or multiple reaction vessels [51,52] and in all cases prepared the bimetallic alloys in solution without a support or prior to deposition on a support making the syntheses less controllable or less efficient. The use of base metal components requires stronger reductants than are typically employed for readily reducible noble metal systems. Results presented in this work for NiPt and CuPt systems highlight key variables and provide relevant guidance for the controlled synthesis of bimetallic alloys via redox mechanism. In this paper, the one-pot synthesis of NiPt and CuPt bimetallic alloys by redox deposition is presented. Initially, silica-supported Ni or Cu seed metals are formed by the reduction of Ni2+ and Cu2+ with NaBH4 at room temperature, followed by the reduction of Pt ions by Ni or Cu metal. Different base metal-to-Pt ratios were explored to determine their effect on bimetallic alloy formation and to explain the steps involved in redox deposition. Reference samples were also prepared for NiPt and CuPt by sequential impregnation method. The catalysts were then evaluated for methane oxidation at 300-400 °C and atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The support used in this study was a fumed silica (Cabosil, L-90, surface area of 90 m2/g). The metal precursors used were NiCl2·6H2O (Wako, 99.9%), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%), CuCl2·2H2O (Aldrich, 99.99%), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Wako, 99.9%) and H2PtCl6·6H2O (Wako, 98.5%). The reducing agent used was NaBH4 (TCI, > 95%). The gases used for reactivity tests were methane (99.999%), 20% oxygen in helium (certified mixture grade), and argon (99.9%). The gas used for catalyst pretreatment was hydrogen (99.999%). The gases were all purchased from Tokyo Koatsu Yamazaki Co. Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation by the redox deposition (RD) method Silica-supported MAPt (MA = Ni, Cu) bimetallic catalysts with different molar ratios were prepared by varying the amounts of Ni or Cu while maintaining the loading of Pt constant at 2 wt.% (0.10 mmol/gsupport). The samples were denoted as MAPt (4:1), MAPt (2:1), and MAPt (1:1), where the numbers in parentheses are molar ratios. The catalysts were prepared using a one-pot redox deposition method as illustrated in Fig. 1 . Initially, 2.5 g of silica (41.6 mmol) was dispersed in 100 mL of deionized water and stirred at 400 rpm for 10 min. Then based on the desired molar ratios for MAPt as summarized in Table 1 , an appropriate amount of NiCl2·6H2O or CuCl2·2H2O (0.25-1.0 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water and added to the silica/water mixture under continuous stirring. The system was continuously purged with argon. To reduce the MA precursor use was made of a stoichiometric amount of NaBH4 (0.51-2.0 mmol) dissolved in 15 mL of deionized water. The solution was added dropwise to the mixture under Ar and this led to a change in color from green to black for Ni or light blue to wine red for Cu. After stirring for 1.5 h, an aqueous solution of H2PtCl6·6H2O (0.25 mmol) was slowly added to the suspension and stirred for 1.5 h under Ar atmosphere. The pH of the suspension at each stage was measured using a Horiba D-51 pH meter. The solid samples were recovered by filtration and washed several times in order to remove sodium, chlorine, and boron ions. The solid sample was then dried overnight at 110 °C and then pelletized and sieved to a size of 650-1180 μm. Finally, the catalysts were reduced at 400 °C under hydrogen (1000 cm3 min-1 g-1 catalyst) for 2 h and then passivated under 0.2 % O2/He flow (100 cm3 min-1 g-1 catalyst) for 3 h. Monometallic Ni and Cu supported over silica were also prepared with nominal metal loadings similar to those of NiPt (4:1) and CuPt (4:1) prepared by the redox deposition method. Silica supported bimetallic NiPt (IW) and CuPt (IW) reference samples were prepared by conventional co-impregnation using the incipient wetness (IW) method. Metal loadings were chosen to match those measured by XRF (Table 2 ) for NiPt (4:1) and CuPt (4:1) catalysts synthesized by the redox deposition method. For the IW method use was made of aqueous solutions of 0.080 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.28 mmol) and 0.13 g of H2PtCl6·6H2O (0.098 mmol) or 0.11 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.45 mmol) and 0.13 g of H2PtCl6·6H2O (0.097 mmol) on 2.5 g of silica (41.6 mmol), followed by drying overnight at 110 °C and calcination at 400 °C for 4 h. The measured contents of NiPt (IW) and CuPt (IW) agree with the nominal loadings (Table 2). The samples were then pelletized and sieved to a size of 650-1180 μm. Finally, the samples were reduced and passivated under the same conditions used for the samples prepared by the redox deposition method. Another series of NiPt samples were also prepared by the redox deposition method with additional NaBH4 added to fully reduce metal ions. The nominal loadings were the same as those of NiPt (4:1), NiPt (2:1) and NiPt (1:1). The method used was similar to the previous except 1.5 h after the addition of Pt (Fig. 1 (d)), an aqueous solution of NaBH4 was again added. The amount was just enough to reduce all the remaining metal ions in the solution (Table 1). The motivation behind synthesizing these samples was to ensure full reduction of both metals, and will be discussed later. These samples were denoted as NiPt (4:1)*, NiPt (2:1)* and NiPt (1:1)*. 2.3 Characterization Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out under H2 with a TPD-1-AT BEL equipped with a quadruple mass spectrometer. A quantity of 0.10 g of the as-prepared catalyst was placed inside a quartz reactor and was treated at 200 °C for 2 h under He and then cooled to 50 °C under He. The sample was then heated from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C/min under H2 (100 cm3 min-1) while monitoring the water signal (m/z = 18) to obtain the catalyst reduction profile. The BET surface areas of the samples after reduction and passivation were determined from the linear portion (P/P○ = 0.01-0.20) of the N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K using a BELSORP mini II micropore size analyzer. Prior to the analysis, all the samples were dried and evacuated at 120 °C for 3 h. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured for each catalyst before and after reduction with a diffractometer (Rigaku RINT 2400) operated at 40 kV and 100 mA, using a Cu Kα monochromatic X-ray source. The crystallite size (Dc ) of the reduced catalysts was calculated from the line broadening of the most intense peak at 2θ = 39.9-41.8° (111) using the Scherrer equation [54], Dc = K λ /β cos(θ), where K is the constant taken as 0.9, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (0.1541 nm), β is the width of the (111) peak at half-maximum corrected for instrumental broadening (0.1°), and 2θ is the Brag angle. Uptakes of carbon monoxide (CO) were used to titrate the surface metal atoms with the same equipment used for the TPR analysis. The samples were first reduced at 400 °C for 2 h in H2 flow and then cooled to 50 °C in He, following which, calibrated pulses of CO in a He flow (3 % CO/He gas) were introduced and monitored by a mass spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the surface of the samples using a PHI 5000 Versaprobe equipped with a Mg Kα X-ray source (1486.7 eV). The samples were reduced at 400 °C under H2for 2 h and passivated under 0.2 % O2/He for 3 h prior to the XPS measurement. Metal contents for the as-prepared catalysts were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy using a Shimadzu Rayny EDX-800HS. Although the samples were exposed to the atmosphere during handling, the metal ratios were likely not affected greatly because the samples were passivated. 2.4 Activity tests The catalytic tests for methane combustion were carried out in a 1.0-cm o.d/0.75-cm i.d, 27.5 cm long quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor in a temperature range of 300-400 °C at atmospheric pressure. A quantity of 0.3 g of catalyst was loaded into a 2 cm section in the center of the reactor. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated in hydrogen for 2 h at 400 °C. The reactant gas at a total flow rate of 100 cm3 (NTP) min-1 consisted of 20 mol% methane, 3 mol% oxygen, 11.6 mol% helium (internal standard) and argon (balance gas). The reaction temperature was varied in the following order: 400, 350, 300, 325 and 375 °C. The obtention of smooth conversion curves following this order is evidence for catalyst stability and lack of deactivation. The catalyst was first stabilized at 400 °C and atmospheric pressure for 4 h under the reactant stream. The products were analyzed on-line using two gas chromatographs: a Shimadzu GC-2010 equipped with a barrier discharge ionization detector (BID) and a Restek capillary column (30 m ×0.32 mm i.d. × 10 μm film diameter) and a Shimadzu GC-8A equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a molecular sieve 5A (3 m ×3 mm i.d) column. Methane conversion was calculated from the moles of carbon of all observed products divided by the initial moles of methane. Oxygen balance closed to 100 ± 5 %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis method As described in the experimental section, the catalyst synthesis started with the suspension of the SiO2 support (Fig. 1 (a)) in distilled water with the pH of this suspension being 6.1. This was followed by the addition of an aqueous solution of the primary metal precursor (NiCl2·6H2O or CuCl2·2H2O) (Fig.1 (b)) to provide a source of dissociated Ni2+ or Cu2+ ions. The addition of Ni and Cu precursors decreased the pH of the suspensions to 4.6 and 4.3. Then, a stoichiometric amount of NaBH4 was added to the mixture under Ar atmosphere (Fig. 1 (c)) to form metallic Ni or Cu particles adhered to the silica, as in the deposition precipitation method. The addition of NaBH4 increased the pH of the Ni/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 suspensions to 5.8 and 5.6, which was attributed to the alkalinity of Na. The next step consisted of the addition of the secondary metal precursor (H2PtCl6·6H2O) to the solution containing the preformed Ni or Cu metallic clusters (Fig. 1 (d)). The platinum metal precursor was dissociated into platinum chloride ions ([PtCl6]2-), which were subsequently reduced by the metallic Ni or Cu clusters. The addition of Pt precursor decreased the pH of the NiPt/SiO2 suspension from 5.8 to 5.1 and the CuPt/SiO2 suspension from 5.6 to 4.8, which was attributed to the increase in H+ ion concentration due to the dissociation of H2PtCl6·6H2O. The equations below illustrate the reduction of [PtCl6]2- ion to Pt metal by Ni metal, where the standard electrode potentials vs. the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) are given in parenthesis [55]: 2 N i → 2 N i 2 + + 4 e - ( E N i ° = + 0.25 V ) P t C l 6 2 - + 2 e - → P t C l 4 2 - + 2 C l - E P t C l 6 2 - ° = + 0.68 V P t C l 4 2 - + 2 e - → P t + 4 C l - E P t C l 4 2 - ° = + 0.75 V P t C l 6 2 - + 2 N i → P t + 2 N i 2 + + 6 C l - Δ E T o t a l ° = + 1.68 V As evident from the above, the total reduction potential for the NiPt system was greater than zero (ΔEo Total = +1.68 V) and was favorable for the reaction to proceed as written. Similar equations can also be written for the CuPt system with a total reduction potential (ΔEo Total = +1.09 V) as shown below: 2 C u → 2 C u 2 + + 4 e - Δ E C u ° = - 0.34 V P t C l 6 2 - + 2 e - → P t C l 4 2 - + 2 C l - E P t C l 6 2 - ° = + 0.68 V P t C l 4 2 - + 2 e - → P t + 4 C l - E P t C l 4 2 - ° = + 0.75 V P t C l 6 2 - + 2 C u → P t + 2 C u 2 + + 6 C l - Δ E T o t a l ° = + 1.09 V Hence, the mechanism involved the reduction of the secondary metal ions by the primary metals. The oxidized primary metal ion then dissolved in the solution: Ni2+ (Ni → Ni2+ + 2e-) or Cu2+ (Cu → Cu2+ + 2e-). Fig. 2 depicts the proposed mechanism for redox deposition. For the MAPt (2:1) and MAPt (1:1) catalysts, the redox equation indicates that all the amount of primary metals should be used to reduce the Pt ions, in agreement with the XRF results which showed that more than 95% of the primary metals were dissolved when compared to their nominal loading. For the MAPt (4:1) samples, half of the initially added primary metal should be oxidized to Ni2+ and Cu2+ ions (Fig. 2 (c)), consistent with XRF results that half of the original amounts of Ni and Cu of these samples were dissolved. The less drastic loss of Ni and Cu cations in MAPt (4:1) compared to MAPt (2:1) is consistent with the higher amount of MA seed metals available to reduce Pt. This sequence can be further understood from the XRF results of NiPt (4:1)*, NiPt (2:1)* and NiPt (1:1)* catalyst, prepared by adding NaBH4 to the solution after completion of the redox deposition method (Fig. 1(d)). This was done to reduce all the dissolved Ni and Pt ions in the solution. For example, to prepare the NiPt (4:1)*, after synthesis of NiPt (4:1) enough NaBH4 (1.0 mmol) was added (Table 1) to reduce all the dissolved Ni metal ions in the solution. Since the synthesis of NiPt (4:1) started with 1.0 mmol of Ni to reduce 0.25 mmol of Pt ion, in the process, 0.50 mmol of Ni metal were oxidized to Ni2+ ions while reducing the 0.25 mmol of Pt4+ ion (2 moles of Ni to reduce 1 mole of Pt ion). To reduce these 0.50 mmol of Ni2+ ions an amount of 1.0 mmol of NaBH4 was added to the catalyst solution (Ni2+ + 2BH4- + 6H2O → Ni + 2H3BO3 + 7H2). The same reasoning was used to prepare NiPt (2:1)* and NiPt (1:1)* samples (Table 1). A comparison of the measured Ni contents for NiPt (4:1)*, NiPt (2:1)* and NiPt (1:1)* to their NiPt counterparts (Table 2) shows that the addition of NaBH4 helped recover displaced Ni species through re-reduction of Ni2+ ions in the solution onto the support. A comparison of the Pt contents of the two series provides additional insights. For the samples with higher Ni contents, no significant difference in Pt content was observed, suggesting that almost all of the platinum ions were reduced by Ni metal prior to the addition of NaBH4 in the NiPt* catalyst. In the case of NiPt (1:1), however, there was not enough reduced Ni metal (0.10 mmol) to reduce all the Pt ions (0.10), as evident from the measured Pt content of 0.063 mmol compared to the nominal 0.10 mmol. For NiPt (1:1)*, the addition of NaBH4 helped to retain close to 0.098 mmol of Pt metal, suggesting that loss of Pt in NiPt (1:1) was due to insufficient Ni seed metal atoms to reduce all the Pt ions. This is consistent with the stoichiometric equation, demonstrating that the XRF results are in good agreement with the proposed synthesis steps. The XRF measurements of all the samples did not show the presence of Na, Cl or B, indicating that they were removed during washing. 3.2 X-ray diffractions (XRD) Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns for the NiPt and CuPt catalysts prepared by the redox deposition method. The diffraction pattern for monometallic Pt before reduction (Fig. 3 (a), (b)) showed peaks at 2θ = 39.7° and 46.2° corresponding to the (111) and (200) planes in fcc Pt (PDF#04-0802). The diffraction patterns for the NiPt and CuPt catalysts before reduction (Fig. 3(a) and 3(b)) showed clear shifts to higher 2θ values compared to those of monometallic Pt. The shifts to higher angle agree with previous results of NiPt [56,57,58,59] and Cu-Pt alloys [60,61], and give evidence for the formation of alloys even before the reduction treatment. The shifts to higher angle are consistent with the smaller metallic radius of Ni (125 pm) or Cu (128 pm) compared to metallic Pt (139 pm) [62], causing contraction of the Pt lattice structure and increasing the diffraction angles. The formation of NiPt and CuPt alloys at room temperature is due to the selective, redox-driven reduction of Pt by Ni and Cu, as well as the favorable enthalpy of mixing between Pt and Ni (−15 kJ mol-1 [63]) and Pt and Cu (−16 kJ mol-1 [64]). Fig. 3(a) and 3(b) also show that the shifts became larger as the Ni or Cu content increases, in line with the decrease in the Pt lattice constant (Table 3 ). Fig. 3(c) and (d) show the diffraction patterns for the samples after hydrogen reduction at 400 °C. The diffraction pattern for monometallic Pt after H2 reduction at 400 °C (Fig. 3(c), (d)) shows peaks at 2θ = 39.7° and 46.2° corresponding to the (111) and (200) planes in fcc Pt metal. For the NiPt samples, the diffraction peaks became sharper and were shifted toward higher diffraction angle. The sharpening of the diffraction peaks indicates the growth of metal particles by the thermal treatment which also favors alloy formation. This behavior was also observed for the CuPt series (Fig. 3(d)). Thermal treatment of the sample increases the contribution to the entropy of mixing and favors alloy formation [65]. In addition to the NiPt and CuPt samples, NiPd and CuPd samples were prepared using the redox deposition method to demonstrate its application to other base metal-noble metal systems. The XRD patterns of these samples (Fig S2, Supplementary Information) give clear evidence for the formation of phase-pure CuPd and NiPd alloys. Fig. 4 compares XRD patterns of the NiPt series with NiPt* catalysts prepared by adding NaBH4 after completion of the redox deposition to reduce the oxidized Ni and Cu cations in the solution. The shift to higher angles from the positions for Pt metal for the as-prepared and reduced NiPt* samples is enhanced compared to their NiPt counterpart. The enhanced shift to higher angles is consistent with the incorporation of re-adsorbed Ni in the NiPt alloy. Reference samples for NiPt (4:1) and CuPt (4:1) were also prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method and were denoted as NiPt (IW) and CuPt (IW). The samples were prepared with identical metal loadings as those determined by XRF analysis, and were reduced and passivated under the same conditions used for the samples prepared by the redox deposition method. Fig. 5 shows the diffraction patterns for the reduced samples. The peaks for the samples prepared by the impregnation method were broader and less intense, indicating that the particles were smaller and less crystallized. The NiPt (IW) sample also showed a peak corresponding to the (111) reflection of metallic Ni, indicating the formation of individual Ni clusters in addition to the NiPt alloys. For the CuPt (IW) catalyst (Fig. 5), the asymmetrical diffraction peak was deconvoluted into two features at 2θ = 41.3°, corresponding to CuPt, and at 2θ = 42.1°, corresponding to Cu3Pt [66]. This indicates that the samples prepared by the IW method produces a mixture of phases. The crystallite sizes of CuPt (IW) calculated from the Scherrer equation were 5 nm (CuPt) and 11 nm (Cu3Pt). The diffraction peak for CuPt (4:1) indicates the presence of a single CuPt phase. Thus, the redox deposition method is more favorable for the formation of phase-pure bimetallic alloys compared to traditional impregnation method. Table 3 summarizes the lattice parameters for the catalysts after reduction using the XRD peak positions of the (111) and (200) planes of the catalysts synthesized by the RD method and IW method. The lattice parameters were used to calculate the lattice contractions in the bimetallic samples compared to monometallic Pt: L a t t i c e c o n t r a t i o n o f b i m e t a l % = L a t t i c e p a r a m e t e r a P t – l a t t i c e p a r a m e t e r a ( b i m e t a l ) l a t t i c e p a r a m e t e r a P t × 100 The lattice contraction in the NiPt samples decreased in the following order NiPt (4:1) < NiPt (2:1) < NiPt (1:1), as expected for the larger content of the smaller-sized base metal atoms. The lattice contractions for NiPt (4:1) and NiPt (IW) were comparable, but these were larger than those in NiPt (2:1) and NiPt (1:1). The lattice contractions in CuPt catalyst followed the same trend as NiPt: CuPt (4:1) < CuPt (2:1) < CuPt (1:1). There is a significant difference in the lattice contraction between NiPt and CuPt samples. This is because the radius of Ni (125 pm) is farther from Pt (139 pm) than Cu (128 pm), and this may have limited the movement of Ni atoms by diffusion in Pt. Table 3 also summarizes the theoretical values of lattice parameter (atheor ) for the homogeneously alloyed bimetals calculated from Vegard’s law, which assumes a linear relationship between the alloy content and lattice parameter. These theoretical values were calculated using the metal content from the XRF measurement. The deviation of the lattice parameters calculated from the XRD peak positions (aexp ) from the values predicted by Vegard’s law [(aexp -atheor )/atheor ] was then used to calculate the degree of alloying in the bimetallic materials (Table 3) [67,68]. The degree of alloying was high for all the samples, which is consistent with the favorable enthalpy of formation of NiPt [63] and CuPt [64] alloys. Other synthesis methods have been reported similar to the RD method described here. One of these methods is the electroless deposition method (ED) [36,37,39]. However, the use of an electroless bath containing the reducing agent and the more noble metal precursor presents practical challenges because it might prevent the reduction of cations by the reducing agent prior to deposition. To address this, Iglesia and co-workers combined the colloidal and surface redox methods for a one-pot galvanic displacement synthesis of PdAu [41], PtAu [42] and PdPt [43] bimetallic compounds. The method involved the use of a mild reducing agent (ethanol or ethylene glycol) to first reduce solvated Pd or Pt ions, which in turn then reduced Au cations with subsequent re-deposition of the displaced Pd or Pt cations. The authors demonstrated that the use of a mild reducing agent ensured that Au cations were reduced by Pd or Pt instead of by the reducing agent. It has been verified in this study that this protocol fails to produce base metal-noble metal compositions because the base metal cannot be reduced. In addition, the use of a protecting polymer to prevent agglomeration of the colloids in solution necessitates thermal treatment prior to their use as catalysts which can lead to aggregation and sintering. Therefore, a surface redox method that does not require the use of an electroless bath and a protecting polymer simplifies the synthesis of bimetallic alloys, particularly of those involving base metal-noble metal combinations. The synthesis of bimetallic NiPt [49,56,69,70] and CuPt [50,71] alloys by the galvanic displacement method has been reported. Although the preparations involved the use of NaBH4 to first reduce Ni or Cu, followed by the addition of a Pt precursor, as done here, the methods employed excess reducing agent. To avoid the reduction of Pt by NaBH4 an amount of NaBH4 corresponding to the stoichiometric amount of Ni or Cu precursor needs to be used, as we have done. However, the previously reported studies used excess amounts of NaBH4, strongly suggesting that Pt cations were preferentially reduced by NaBH4 instead of by the Ni clusters in the solution. It has been reported that the formation of bimetallic clusters via a redox mechanism is dictated by differences in reduction potentials of the two component metals, as well as their mixing enthalpies [41,42,43]. Although the preparation is not optimized, the findings presented here for NiPt and CuPt systems provide guidelines for the controlled synthesis of noble metal-base metal pairs. Although the particle size of the bimetallic particles obtained by the RD method was relatively large, and improvements are needed, this drawback is offset by the formation of phase pure bimetallic nanoparticles at room temperature using a method that can be extended to other compositions (NiPt, CuPt, NiPd, and CuPd). 3.3 Temperature-programmed reduction Fig. 6 shows the evolution of water (m/z = 18) during the reduction of NiPt and NiPt* samples with different Ni content. No reduction peaks were observed for the bare SiO2 support, indicating that the peaks from the profiles were associated with the reduction of the metal constituents. The TPR traces were fitted with Gaussian functions to extract the peak maxima. The profile for monometallic Pt showed a shoulder and a reduction peak at 350 °C. The shoulder is attributed to the reduction of surface platinum oxide species and the higher-temperature peak is ascribed to the reduction of bulk platinum oxide interacting with the support [72,73]. The shoulder, which is present in the profiles of all Pt-containing samples, has been previously observed in silica-supported NiPt alloys [74]. The profile for monometallic Ni revealed a broad reduction feature at 421 °C. The lower reduction temperature of the monometallic Pt sample compared to the monometallic Ni sample reflects the known easier reducibility of platinum [75,76] over nickel [47]. The TPR profiles for NiPt (1:1) and NiPt (2:1) showed a peak at 348 and 349 °C, corresponding to the reduction of platinum, while the peak associated with the reduction of nickel was not observed. The intensity of the reduction peak for platinum is linked to the amount of Ni available to reduce platinum metal ions during the redox reaction. For the NiPt (1:1) sample, the relatively small reduction peak for platinum is due to the low Pt content as there is not enough nickel available in NiPt (1:1) to reduce all the platinum since 1 mole of Pt4+ ions requires 2 moles of Ni metal (2Ni → 2Ni2+ + 4e-). Fig. 6 shows a small but obvious shift to lower temperature of the reduction peak for platinum in NiPt (1:1) and NiPt (2:1) compared to monometallic Pt. Although the shift is small it likely originated from the presence of a small amount of Ni in the Pt structure which altered the reducibility of platinum oxide. A similar shift to lower temperature has been observed before [77]. As Ni content is increased, a peak associated with the reduction of Ni is observed. This indicates that the Pt and Ni components in the alloys reduce at different temperatures. Moreover, the reduction peak of Ni for NiPt (4:1) shifted to lower temperature compared to monometallic Ni catalyst, attributed to hydrogen spillover from Pt to Ni2+ species in close proximity [77]. These shifts in temperatures are consistent with the formation of Ni-Pt alloys [77,78]. The reduction profiles of the NiPt* samples provide further evidence of the effect of higher Ni content on Ni-Pt alloy formation. Fig. 6 shows a more intense reduction peak and an enhanced shift to lower temperature of the Pt reduction peak for NiPt (1:1)* compared to NiPt (1:1). This is linked to the higher amount of Ni metal atoms available in NiPt* to reduce Pt ions. The profiles for the higher Ni contents, (NiPt (2:1)* and NiPt (4:1)*), showed a shift to higher temperatures of the Pt and Ni reduction peaks. The intensity of the Ni reduction feature was enhanced compared to the corresponding peak of the NiPt counterpart. As was previously explained, the addition of NaBH4 at the end of the synthesis re-reduced displaced Ni cations in solution which were subsequently incorporated into the bimetallic alloy. Notably, the higher reduction temperature peak of NiPt (1:1)* is not visible even after the addition of NaBH4 which further confirms that the amount of Ni in a 1:1 molar ratio is insufficient to reduce all the Pt during redox deposition. The TPR profile for NiPt (IW) had a sharp maximum at 234 °C and a lower-temperature shoulder, and was consistent with a previous result for silica-supported NiPt prepared using the incipient wetness method [77]. The sharp peak was at a lower temperature than any of the reduction peaks from NiPt catalysts, probably due to the smaller sizes of NiPt (IW) particles (Table 4 ) [76]. Fig. 7 shows the TPR profiles for the as-prepared CuPt series with different Cu content prepared by the redox deposition method. In contrast to the Ni-containing series, the Cu-containing samples had reduction peaks with diminished intensity, suggesting that the components in the CuPt alloys were already in reduced form. This behavior is reasonable. Since the samples prepared by the redox deposition method were exposed to the ambient prior to TPR measurement, the difference in TPR profiles between the two series is probably related to the lower oxidation potential for Cu/Cu2+ (Eo Cu = -0.32 V) compared to Ni/Ni2+ (Eo Ni = +0.25 V) which made Cu in the as-prepared CuPt samples less susceptible to re-oxidation. The profiles for the CuPt samples showed a broad reduction feature with a maximum between the reduction temperature of monometallic Cu and monometallic Pt. This suggests that Pt and Cu species in the alloy were reduced simultaneously. There is a consistent shift to higher temperature with increasing Cu content, suggesting that the reduction of the components became more difficult due to Cu-Pt interactions. The shifts are evidence for alloy formation and are consistent with a favorable heat of formation of Cu-Pt alloys [79]. Two reference samples were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation and used to ascertain the reduction temperature for Cu and Pt. The Cu (IW) sample showed two main reduction peaks centered at 200 °C, attributed to the reduction of Cu2O, and 230 °C, assigned to the reduction of CuO [80,81]. The CuPt (IW) sample had a low-temperature shoulder and a prominent reduction peak at 178 °C. Although Cu and CuPt (4:1) prepared by the RD method have similar contents to Cu (IW) and CuPt (IW), the TPR profiles were different. The absence of the reduction peaks of Cu (IW) and CuPt (IW) from the CuPt samples confirms that Cu and Pt components in the CuPt samples are already in their reduced form. 3.4 BET surface areas and CO uptakes Table 4 shows the BET surface areas (m2 g-1) and CO uptake (μmol gmetal -1) of the fresh and spent catalysts. The fresh catalysts are the samples reduced in hydrogen at 400 °C. The specific surface areas were between 75 to 92 m2 g-1 and were close to that of the support (86 m2 g-1). The BET surface area did not change significantly after reactivity testing, indicating that the textural properties of the catalyst were unaffected during the reaction. The CO uptake for monometallic Ni catalyst was higher than for monometallic Pt, suggesting higher dispersion of Ni on silica. For the NiPt series, CO uptakes increased with increasing Ni content which is consistent with the formation of an alloy with Ni preferentially occupying the surface of Pt. The CO uptakes for the CuPt series were an order of magnitude lower than the NiPt series, a consequence of the intrinsic property of Cu. It is known that CO adsorbs reversibly on metallic Cu0 surface and irreversibly on Cu+ surface [82,83]; therefore, the minimal CO uptake capacity is consistent with Cu existing mainly in the metallic form in Cu-containing samples as suggested by TPR (section 3.3) and XPS (section 3.5). The results suggest surface enrichment by Cu in CuPt alloys and agree with previous spectroscopic [84] and low-energy ion scattering [86] measurements of bimetallic CuPt nanoparticles after hydrogen treatment. Therefore, the CO uptake values listed are an underestimation of the available metal sites on the surface of CuPt catalysts. The CO uptake of the spent catalysts decreased after the methane oxidation reaction, indicating that the catalysts sintered during the reaction. The crystallite sizes (Dc) from XRD line-broadening calculated by the Scherrer equation are somewhat large, and this is partly due to the low surface area of the silica support. The Dc values show that the preparation method is not optimized. Improvements can be envisioned in the concentration of the active components used and the temperature of synthesis. The average particle size from XRD analysis for NiPt (4:1) is 3 nm and for CuPt (4:1) is 7 nm, and these are lower than those obtained from transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Fig. S3), as the latter cannot detect smaller particles. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 8 (a) shows the Pt 4f core-level spectra of reduced (400 °C in hydrogen) and passivated Pt and NiPt catalysts. Table 5 lists the binding energies for Pt 4f 5/2, Pt 4f 7/2, Ni 2p 1/2, Ni 2p 3/2, Cu 2p 1/2 and Cu 2p 3/2 core levels. The Pt 4f 5/2 and Pt 4f 7/2 signals for monometallic Pt appeared at 74.2 eV and 70.8 eV, and are assigned to metallic Pt [59,86]. In addition, shoulder peaks at 74.4 eV and 71.4 eV are assigned to Pt2+ in the passivation layer or interacting with the silica support [86,87]. The Pt 4f signals for both the NiPt (4:1) and NiPt (IW) samples shifted slightly to higher binding energy compared to those for monometallic Pt. The positive shift is attributed to charge transfer between Pt and Ni. Although Pt (2.28) is more electronegative than Ni (1.91) [88], electron transfer from Pt to Ni is not unreasonable if the surface Pt was in reduced form and the surface Ni was in oxidized form before reduction by hydrogen. It can be inferred from the standard redox potentials of Ni and Pt that, upon exposure to the ambient after redox deposition, the Ni component on the surface of the NiPt alloy is more likely to be in oxidized form than the Pt component. For that reason, the electron transfer from Pt to Ni may have occurred during reduction by hydrogen, reminiscent of Pt-induced reduction of Ni2+ under reducing conditions previously reported for the synthesis of bimetallic NiPt alloys [89,90]. Based on the mechanism for the noble metal induced reduction (NMIR) method [3,89,90], it is postulated that Pt attracts and polarizes Ni2+, inducing a partial positive charge on Pt. As a consequence, there is a shift in electron density from Pt to Ni until reduction of Ni2+ is completed. The charge transfer indicates that Pt and Ni must be in close proximity and this gives evidence of Ni-Pt alloy formation, consistent with the findings from XRD and TPR. Fig. 8(b) shows the Ni 2p core-level spectra of the Ni-containing samples. The Ni 2p signal for the monometallic Ni sample showed Ni 2p 1/2 and Ni 2p 3/2 contributions at 874.0 eV and 856.4 eV, which could be assigned to Ni2+ [91]. In addition, broad shake-up satellite peaks at 880.8 eV and 862.2 eV are observed due to multielectron excitation which are characteristics of divalent Ni2+ species [92,93]. These results indicate that surface Ni was mostly in oxidized form and was more susceptible to oxidation than Pt. For the bimetallic samples, the signal intensities for Ni were low because it has a lower X-ray cross-section compared to Pt [94]. The reference NiPt (IW) sample showed a broad Ni 2p 3/2 feature at 854.9 eV assigned to Ni2+ and a satellite peak. An obvious negative shift for the Ni 2p 3/2 peak compared to monometallic Ni is in line with the positive shift for the Pt 4f 3/2 and 4f 5/2 lines compared to monometallic Pt, and points to electron transfer from Pt to Ni. The NiPt samples prepared by redox deposition showed no visible Ni signals, suggesting low coverage of Ni on the surface and gives evidence for surface Pt enrichment in NiPt catalysts. This result is inconsistent with deductions made from CO chemisorption results that Ni preferentially occupies the surface of Pt in the alloy. A plausible reason is that Pt and Ni co-exist on the surface of the alloy. This is supported by predictions by Nørskov and co-workers [95], that the surface of a NiPt alloy will likely have neighbouring Ni and Pt atoms. Fig. 9 (a) shows the Pt 4f core-level spectra for the CuPt samples. There was a shift to higher binding energy of the Pt 4f5/2 and Pt 4f7/2 lines similar to that observed for the NiPt samples. Fig. 9 (b) shows the Cu 2p core-level spectra for the Cu-containing samples. The deconvolution of the spectra revealed two contributions for both the Cu 2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2 peaks. The Cu 2p 1/2 signal at 952.3 eV and the Cu 2p 3/2 peak at 932.4 eV are close to the binding energies previously reported for partially oxidized Cu+ or Cu0. The shoulder peaks at 954.2 eV and 933.9 eV can be assigned to Cu2+ [96,97]. Although Cu+ and Cu0 cannot be distinguished by XPS due to spectral overlap [96,97], it was deduced from CO chemisorption and TPR results that the majority of the surface Cu is in metallic form. Thus, Cu is more resistant to oxidation than Ni after superficial passivation. A small shift to higher binding energy of the Cu0 peak indicates that partial oxidation occurred, although to a lesser extent than the CuPt catalyst prepared by impregnation. In comparing the XPS results of the CuPt and NiPt catalysts, the higher signal intensity for Cu suggests high coverage of Cu in CuPt as a consequence of surface migration, and is likely the reason for the lower CO uptakes of the Cu-containing samples. Surface enrichment of Cu in CuPt catalysts has been previously reported [82,84,[85]]. 3.6 Reactivity Methane combustion activities were evaluated over the NiPt (4:1), CuPt (4:1), Pt/SiO2, Cu/SiO2, Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the redox deposition method and the NiPt (IW), CuPt (IW) catalysts obtained by the impregnation method. These tests were performed to compare the activities of catalysts with identical metal loadings prepared by the redox deposition method and the impregnation method. The (4:1) samples were chosen for the reactivity studies because it was desired to examine the effect of the base metal on the Pt and because the samples had similar compositions as the IW catalysts (Table 2). For all catalysts, the only products observed were CO2 and H2O. Fig. 10 shows turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on CO uptake values and Arrhenius plots for the various catalysts. The conversions in all cases were lower than 10 % in order to be in the kinetic regime. The slope from the Arrhenius plots was used to calculate activation energies (Ea). The results for the Ni-Pt system are shown in Fig. 10(a) and (c). The activities were in the order of NiPt (4:1) >NiPt (IW) > Ni > Pt, although the differences were not large. Both bimetallic NiPt catalysts showed higher TOF values than the separate pure metal catalysts at the highest temperature of 400 ℃. The Ea values were similar for the Ni-containing samples and were higher than those of the Pt catalyst. Since the Ea values were nearly the same for all the nickel-based catalysts, it is considered that the active species could be nickel metal for the methane combustion. Even though the XPS measurements suggest electron transfer from Pt to Ni (Fig. 8), there is probably little ligand effect since the TOFs and activation energies for the alloys were similar to those of pure Ni. The results for the Cu-Pt system are shown in Fig. 10(b) and (d). The activities were in the order of CuPt (4:1) > Cu > CuPt (IW) > Pt. The bimetallic CuPt (4:1) catalyst prepared by the redox deposition method showed a higher TOF than a pure Cu catalyst whereas the CuPt (IW) catalyst that was composed of a mixture of CuPt and Cu3Pt (Fig. 5) had a lower TOF, which was close to that of Pt. This difference in activity between the CuPt (4:1) and CuPt (IW) catalysts cannot be explained by differences in particle size because the calculated crystallite size of the catalysts were similar (Table 4). The difference could be due to the presence of different CuPt phases in the catalysts, as determined by XRD analysis. Thus, these results suggest that the CuPt phase is more active than Cu3Pt phase for methane combustion. Previous studies have reported a difference in the electronic states of Cu and Pt in both Cu3Pt and CuPt, arising from the change in their d-band states due to electronic (ligand) and geometric (strain) effects [98,99]; these changes in the electronic states might be responsible for the difference in catalyst activity. For the Ea values, the order was CuPt (4:1) > CuPt (IW) > Cu > Pt. Unlike the bimetallic NiPt catalysts, the Ea values were different from one another among the copper-based catalysts, indicating a possible ligand effect. The activation energies of the bimetallic NiPt and CuPt catalysts compared to the monometallic Pt catalyst was high. As discussed above, XPS results indicate electron transfer from Pt to Ni and Cu in the bimetallic system, suggesting that the electronic structure of Pt in the NiPt and CuPt catalysts differs from that of Pt in the monometallic Pt catalyst. The change in the electronic behavior probably modified the catalytic sites, leading to different activation energies. Previous investigations were conducted with high O2/CH4 ratios under which Pd and Pt noble metal catalysts showed higher activities than NiO and CuO catalysts (Table 6 ). The results here were obtained at much lower O2/CH4 ratios and the activity order was Cu > Ni > Pt, with lower Ea values. This order is the reverse from that at high O2/CH4 ratios. According to previous work, the O2/CH4 ratio significantly affects the methane catalytic combustion on Pt [100] and Cu catalysts [101]. At O2/CH4 ratio > 2, the surface active sites are totally saturated by chemisorbed oxygen and the reaction rate strongly depends on methane pressure. In contrast, under oxygen-deficient conditions (O2/CH4 ratio < 2), the surface active sites are less occupied by chemisorbed oxygen and more with other intermediates, so the rate then depends on both methane and oxygen. Also, the Ea values are lower than that at high O2/CH4 ratio. Accordingly, the reaction might proceed by a different mechanism on Cu, Ni, Pt metals at low O2/CH4 ratio where Cu, Ni in the metallic state might be able to dissociate CH4 in the vicinity of adsorbed oxygen. Therefore, the result suggests that cheap Cu, Ni and their bimetallic CuPt, NiPt alloys can be promising alternatives as combustion catalysts at low O2/CH4 ratio conditions. 4 Conclusions This work was carried out to demonstrate a new one-pot synthesis method for silica-supported NiPt and CuPt catalysts by means of differences in reduction potentials of the two components. Evidence for the formation of NiPt and CuPt alloys was obtained from XRD patterns, and this was supported by shifts in reduction peak positions from TPR profiles, shifts in binding energies from XPS spectra, and differences in uptakes between monometallic and bimetallic samples from CO chemisorption measurements. Other Ni-Pt and Cu-Pt structures were not detected in the XRD patterns, suggesting the formation of a single phase alloy. Conversely, multiphase species were present in the reference silica-supported NiPt and CuPt catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. A proposed redox formation mechanism, in which a fraction of Ni or Cu acts as sacrificial seed metal atoms to reduce Pt, was supported by XRF results. The fraction of Ni or Cu lost and the extent of bimetallic mixing was found to be strong functions of the amount of Ni or Cu seed metals available to reduce Pt. Additional amounts of NaBH4 were used to recover a majority of the displaced oxidized cations after the redox reaction, which increased the number of base metals available for bimetallic alloy formation. The similarity of the XRD features for both series indicated that NiPt and CuPt alloys have similar bulk characteristics. The relative intensities of XPS signals of the components and the disparity in CO uptakes, however, suggested that NiPt and CuPt have different surface compositions: the coexistence of Ni and Pt atoms on the surface of NiPt alloys and Cu-enrichment on the surface of CuPt alloys. In the methane combustion, prepared NiPt (4:1) and CuPt (4:1) alloy catalysts showed higher TOF values than NiPt (IW) and CuPt (IW) catalysts prepared by a conventional impregnation method as well as separate pure metal catalysts. This activity enhancement was suggested to be due to single phase alloy formation of NiPt and CuPt by the redox deposition method developed in this study. coredata.dc:description: A one-pot redox deposition method is described to prepare silica-supported bimetallic NiPt and CuPt catalysts using differences in standard reduction potentials. The synthesis involved the initial reduction of non-noble metal ions (Ni2+ and Cu2+) by NaBH4, followed by reduction of Pt ions by these reduced metals. Alloy formation and phase purity were established by X-ray diffraction (XRD), bulk composition by X-ray fluorescence (XRF), and surface composition by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Alloy formation was enhanced by increase in the amount of base metals available to reduce Pt, or through the use of excess NaBH4 after redox deposition. The catalysts were evaluated for methane oxidation at 300-400 °C and atmospheric pressure. Reference samples prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation (IW) method had inferior performance and characteristics. The redox deposition method provides a simple and versatile protocol for the preparation of bimetallic alloys between noble metals and base metals.
coredata.dc:title: A New One-Pot Sequential Reduction-Deposition Method for the synthesis of Silica-supported NiPt and CuPt Bimetallic Catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: noble metal and base metal alloy
